name: Kepler-372
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-372 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-372 is a star with 1.2139999999999997 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.14 times its radius. It is located 5091.85 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-372 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-372 b

Kepler-372 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 6.85 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-372.

The mass of Kepler-372 b is 2.00 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-372 b is 1.36 that of Earth. At 2.00 Earth masses, Kepler-372 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-372 c

Kepler-372 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.15 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 20.05 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-372.

The mass of Kepler-372 c is 5.61 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-372 c is 2.09 that of Earth. At 5.61 Earth masses, Kepler-372 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-372 d

Kepler-372 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.20 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 30.09 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-372.

The mass of Kepler-372 d is 3.40 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-372 d is 1.69 that of Earth. At 3.40 Earth masses, Kepler-372 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-372, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
